posts.name: Matt Werner 6128
posts.cooked:
I have finally broken through my summer procrastination and installed Go and Cheesy Arena Lite on our Raspberry Pi FMS for our practice field.

CA Lite is fairly intuitive and I have gotten some random team numbers loaded, created some practice matches and am ready to move back to the field and try it with a robot and driver station.

The screen grab below shows the configuration of the VH-109(113) with the team SSID and WPA on the left and the first practice match queued up on the right.  We have an TL-SG108E switch with the various VLANs configured.  We have used this setup for team testing and have had several teams operating simultaneously.  We are ready to up our game and start having practice matches.

Questions:

Is there a user manual anywhere for Cheesy Arena (Lite)?

Has CA-L been updated to work with the VH-113AP?

Should the radio status turn green at this point?

With just the Pi, Switch, and Radio hooked up should I see anything different on the match status display?

We have an additional large screen monitor, I see configuration for additional displays, but it looks like they need to be on the network to operate.  Any instructions on what is needed to do that?

Appreciate any help, Thanks

20250905_14h01m16s_grim 1920×1080 265 KB

20250905_14h01m16s_grim 1920×1080 265 KB

20250905_14h01m16s_grim 1920×1080 265 KB

posts.name: Tauseef Afraz
posts.cooked: When I last spoke to @Pat_Fairbank and @FletcherS7 when I was planning to create a FMS system for my team, I was told that they usually update Cheesy Arena around summer/before Cheezy Champs. And there was a chance that lite would be merged into the main repo of CA.

posts.name: MetabolicCloth
posts.cooked:
The wiki on GitHub has the most complete documentation Cheesy Arena Wiki

I’d recommend just running the full featured Cheesy Arena, you can ignore the season specific material if you don’t want to use it.

posts.name: Matt Werner 6128
posts.cooked: Thank you,  the wiki is what I was looking for.  I guess Google doesn’t match user manual with wiki.

posts.name: Matt Werner 6128
posts.cooked:
Thanks,  I did read 90% of this, this evening.  Quite a bit of good information about setting up and connecting all the equipment.  A bit of information about the settings in the program, but almost nothing about how you run matches.

There is a section just about running with the VH-109(113) so it is a bit up to date.

With a TL-SG108E it runs with static VLANs, which doesn’t seem to be different than the fancy Cisco iron.

I will continue to look.  Maybe there is another Wiki just from the operation of the arena UI.

Running remote display screens is still a bit of a mystery.  It says to use Chrome to access, but it is using the router’s address of 10.0.100.1.  I need to try just pointing it to 10.0.100.5 FMS .

posts.name: MetabolicCloth
posts.cooked:
For the display point it to your FMS ip address, the display tab will let you open whichever display you’re trying to view. There is also a raspberry pi image that you can use to deploy a display.

Have you been able to connect the AP to CA? Changing team numbers on CA should push the settings to the AP.

Does your DS connect to the FMS ? It should lock out your enable/disable if it’s connected properly.

Once both of those are working the robot is the easy part.

posts.name: Matt Werner 6128
posts.cooked:
Yes, I was able to use my laptop and get to the field_monitor, queueing, audience displays.

When running a match I can get the audience display and audio to all cycle.  I can manually enter scores.  Trial by error but I am getting there.

I have not been able to connect a robot yet. Still working in my home lab.

I have not seen the SSID and wpa change at the VH-119AP.  We did manually run testing with multiple teams last spring with this setup. All manual config of AP. We are trying to get to the next level and run scrimmages.

I see info in the GitHub repository that implies work has been done to make it work with the VH radio.

More tomorrow.

posts.name: Matt Werner 6128
posts.cooked:
Well here is the current status:

I now have a RoboRio, Robot Radio, and DS All connect depending on manual config of 113AP

I switched to Cheesy-Arena   NOT LITE.  Seems to be working fine. I can setup and run Practice Matches if I bypass all teams. DS recognizes connection with radio AP and roborio.  Does not recognize FMS I can run all displays on multiple browsers on multiple machines I am not running Cisco Iron   TP Link SG-108E.  A static config of SG-108E seems adequate for running practice matches. We have no field IO

I can setup and run Practice Matches if I bypass all teams.

DS recognizes connection with radio AP and roborio.  Does not recognize FMS

I can run all displays on multiple browsers on multiple machines

I am not running Cisco Iron   TP Link SG-108E.  A static config of SG-108E seems adequate for running practice matches.

We have no field IO

In Run Match mode CA does nor recognize the connected robot and DS

Every second I am getting a Failed to update access point monitoring: failed to fetch access point status:  Get  “httpe:///status”: http: no Host in the request URL.  This seems to because I checked “Enable advanced network Security” in Setup-Field-Networking.  This was just a trial…

The TL Switch works just fine with a static configuration and manually configuration of the VH-113 AP (VH-109 hardware).

I question my IP MASK setting on the DS and FMS for getting from 10.16.28.x to 10.0.100.x?

I think I only need two things to be able to run practice matches:

Enable AP use without enabling Cisco Switch Requirement

Have DS recognize FMS and CA recognize DS

Any help would be appreciated .  From messages here on CD it seems a number of teams have been trying to make this happen.

Any thoughts? @Pat_Fairbank @FletcherS7 @kiettyyyy

Thanks

posts.name: Matt Werner 6128
posts.cooked:
I have done a bit more testing and it all comes down to network routing between the FMS running CA and the DS for each team.

Last year @kiettyyyy helped me with understanding that the VH-109 running the AP-Practice firmware provided routing and DHCP services.  This resulted in the DS ’s getting addresses in the 10.TE. AM .2## range.  That’s ok for testing, but CA expects them to be at 10.TE. AM .5, which can be easily done with with a fixed IP assignment.

With the AP handling routing functions the need for reconfiguring a Cisco switch seems to go away.  I think that means that any Managed Switch with VLAN support will work.  I am rereading the VH information about the AP firmware and I see there is an update and firmware V1.2.9.  I see in the documentation

The access point will now be reachable via the DS port at ** 10.0.100.2 **after the firmware upgrade is complete

The access point will be configurable via the FIRST FMS , Cheezy Arena or the built-in configuration web page at http://10.0.100.2/configuration

The access point will be configurable via the FIRST FMS , Cheezy Arena or the built-in configuration web page at http://10.0.100.2/configuration

The access point will be configured to pass traffic on VLAN 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80 and 90 to the 6 GHz wireless interface

The access point will be configured to pass traffic on VLAN 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80 and 90 to the 6 GHz wireless interface

This mentions VLANS 70, 80, & 90 which it didn’t last year.  Are these VLANS used for the 10.0.100.### subnet?

Am I missing something with the configuration of IP Mask and IP Gateway in the setup of the IP addresses on the FMS and DS stations?  What should those values be?

MiStem Region 9 Practice Field Communications Configuration.pdf (1.0 MB)

posts.name: Matt Werner 6128
posts.cooked:
Hello All, @kiettyyyy @Pat_Fairbank @FletcherS7 @DavidMasin

I have made a lot of progress that I will enumerate below, but I have one real issue I need help with.

Commented Lines in Arena Go 1355×914 189 KB

Commented Lines in Arena Go 1355×914 189 KB

Commented Lines in Arena Go 1355×914 189 KB

In @kiettyyyy ‘s post from last year.  He said to comment out lines #836→#840 in arena.go.  With the latest code from GitHub, that now results in an error of mismatched }{}}{}.  Looking at the code I ended up commenting out #839→#842.  The problem is that I am assuming that modifications to the file only added a few lines.  It could have been many more or some were removed.  With the latest version of Cheesy Arena what lines should really be commented out?  Hopefully with a little snap shot so this won’t be an issue next year.  I see intermittent error messages that makes me believe I may not have the correct lines commented out.  Maybe arena.EventSettings.SCCManagmentEnabled should be split into two check boxes that are arena.EventSettings.APManagmentEnabled and arena.EventSettings.SCCManagementEnabled.

TL;DR   Here are some things I discovered while trying to learn how CA works.

With the Raspberry Pi 5 FMS , the IPv4 settings for the IP Mask setting is the style with /8, /16, /24 (CIDR Notation) etc.  Make sure to remember that /24 refers to the number of bits defining the subnet, not the number of bits to define the devices within the subnet.

Suggested values in the settings, shown in Red, do not automatically apply!  You must enter and save the value you want used, even if it is the same.  The IP address of the Access point being the most pertinent to my trouble.

The Team WPA Keys are EMPTY by default!  You must either generate random Keys or edit each team’s entry to specify a Key.  (I like **TEAM#**robot)  We have a practice field with scrimmage matches.

I spent a lot of time with trial and error with all the features of CA.  There must be a class for FTA ’s that I haven’t found.  I will be expanding my instructions for our practice field to provide an overview of instructions on how to configure and use CA.

I will post my updated user guide here in a week or so.

posts.name: David
Matt Werner 6128
posts.cooked:
Hello All,

Thanks @DavidMasin Your note is the missing link I needed.  I no longer have intermittent error messages about the missing SCC switch.

@kiettyyyy I am attaching my updated documentation on configuring the network infrastructure for a practice field using a VH-109 AP (VH-113), a TL-SG108-E Switch and a Raspberry Pi 5 as the FMS hosting Cheesy Arena.

I have collected information found in numerous CD posts and collected them in one place. I hope this is helpful to other teams setting up practice fields with the hopes of hosting practice scrimmage matches.

Anyone that finds errors or omissions in this document let me know and I will post updates.

MiStem Region 9 Practice Field Communications Configuration With Cheesy.pdf (2.4 MB)

posts.name: Tauseef Afraz
posts.cooked:
mlwerner:

Raspberry Pi 5 as the FMS hosting Cheesy Arena

Would you recommend running Cheesy Arena on a RPi 5 or would a PC be better?

posts.name: Matt Werner 6128
posts.cooked:
It runs fine on the pi 5. Previously there wasn’t a native go compiler but now there is.

Maybe if you had a full PLC scoring system it might have speed limitations, but for running 6 team matches with manual scoring it runs great. I have had three browsers connected with multiple tabs.

posts.name: Matt Werner 6128
posts.cooked:
Hey All,

I just updated our second practice Field Pi with Cheesy Arena.  The location that needs to be commented out in arena.go has moved again.  I also see that the SCC switch configuration has received its own enable check box in Setup.

With the new check box it may not be necessary to comment out this code.

I will give it a whirl and update here.

posts.name: Tauseef Afraz
posts.cooked:
I’m a little confused about the setup. Since the VH AP firmware can connect to the Driver Station over VLANs and to the other radios using the team number and WPA key, how does that work with CA?

Do we still need to enter the team number and WPA key directly on the VH AP, which then passes the team number into CA? Or  do you program the radios through the kiosk, and which will change the team number in CA automatically?

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked:
TFM110:

Do we still need to enter the team number and WPA key directly on the VH AP, which then passes the team number into CA? Or do you program the radios through the kiosk, and which will change the team number in CA automatically?

The web interface is a frontend for the http API, which the kiosk/cheesy arena use to configure the robot radio/AP. If you’re using cheesy arena, you shouldn’t be configuring the AP through the AP’s web interface as that will wipe away whatever cheesy arena configured.

The kiosk is used when using randomly generated keys (ie. from the FMS ) so humans never have to know or type in a key and other settings manually; manual configuration through the web interface is otherwise functionally identical currently.

posts.name: Tauseef Afraz
posts.cooked: So, let’s say I’m hosting a small scrimmage for local teams. I don’t need a kiosk, I just need to enter the team number into CA, right?
